work.p: The second paragraph of this prose manuscript consists of lines that appeared in a slightly altered form in the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, which was ultimately titled "Song of Myself": "Backward I see in my own days where I sweated through fog with linguists and contenders, / I have no mockings or arguments . . . . I witness and wait" (1855, p. 15).

titleStmt.title: After all is said and
a machine readable transcription

notesStmt.note: The second paragraph of this prose manuscript appeared in a slightly altered form in the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, the poem ultimately titled "Song of Myself." This would suggest that the manuscript was probably written between 1850 and 1855.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: It is no miracle now that we are to live on always
bibl.orgName: Trent Collection of Whitmaniana, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
On the back of this manuscript leaf is a draft of poetic lines about touch related to sections 28 to 30 in the final version of "Song of Myself."

revisionDesc.change: transcribed and encoded; revised Archive ID
metadata extracted and transformed from EAD file

body.p: Allfter all that can be is said and done in the way of argument, the innumerable it the whole amount to a means but a is a makes raises but bubble of the sea-ooze in comparison with against that unspeakable Something in my own soul which makes me know without being able to tell how it is or prove how that is I know.—If Though I were opposed by what I felt the science linguists and lore of the whole earth deny what I say, it amounts but to this: So it seems to them.—I simply answer, So it seems to me.—The greatest of thoughts and truths, are not never to be put in language writing or print..—They are not susceptible of proof like a sum in simple multiplication

p.seg: I caneven see myself struggling sweating in the fog with the linguists and learned old men.—I look back upon that time in my own days.—
I have no gibes nor mocks mockings or laughter;—I have only to be silent and patiently to wait.—
